name: Beyond Good and Evil™
description: For centuries, the planet Hyllis has been bombarded by a relentless alien race. Skeptical of her government's inability to repel the invaders, a rebellious action reporter named Jade sets out to capture the truth.

So here's this game I played several times on the PS2, and it is SO FUN. PC is no exception.  People may have seen the camera on the box art back in the day and said to themselves 'Ew! Camera in the gameplay, no way!' Sure the camera is sometimes a necessary part of the game, but combat and stealth are major gameplay elements that shouldn't be overlooked.  The story centres on Jade and Pey'j, in a strange world where half-animal people walk around on two legs and talk. For example Pey'j has a definite boar-like appearance. The world is under siege from the Domz armada, and the Alpha Sections are there to stop them. During an attack Jade discovers she's out of credits and her lighthouse shield power is cut off. In an effort to make some credits she takes on a photography job for the local science centre, and through a turn of events ends up working for a secret underground movement called the Iris Network.  The plot is fairly straightforward - you go on missions looking for evidence, once you find the evidence you take photos of it, and then you get the hell outta there. The missions are few and large, and the best way to approach it is to go sneaky stealth mode on everything. It is possible to attack your enemies too, but you will have a hard time.  Gameplay combat is all 3rd-person, but not all of it is melee. There are battles on the water inside your 'tugboat', and towards the end of the game there is even a spaceship battle, which I thoroughly enjoyed. Enemies hit hard in melee combat though, so it pays to grab all the health upgrades you can find. These can be manually distributed to your companion too if you think they need it. As already mentioned, subterfuge is your friend - you will have more fun with sneak attacks and trickery than trying to face-tank your way though the game.  Other gameplay elements include speed-races to get your stolen credits back, minigames (that game in the Akuda Bar is badass hard), finding all the species to photograph for more credits, finding all the pearls for more vehicle upgrades. There are a couple of foot-chases too, to add whipped cream to an already delicious cake of a game.  So how delicious is it? Well the music is a blast for starters. It has a wonderful style to it, melodious and alien. Well-suited to the game. The graphics are a little bland but good - with a main character like Jade it makes sense there's a bit of a green theme to it. Voice-actors have been cast well, there is a lot of great voice-acting in the game and it helps to suspend disbelief, helping immersion and reinforcing our empathy towards the characters.  Highly recommended to anyone that loves stealth, a great story, or just wants to try something new. The hours I've played it on PC are not representative of my total hours (PC and PS2). Worth it just for the soundtrack!

Beyond Good and Evil is one of my favorite games of all time. I jumped in not expecting much, but you gain an attachment to each of the characters and the action just blows you away. It has both combat and stealth sections, plenty of interesting puzzles, and hundreds of collectables to keep you playing. Cant wait for the second game to continue this epic saga.

So why don't you own this game already? I mean seriously!? This is a wonderful action platformer with some fun stealth elements spliced together ina world full of wonder and conspiracy! It may not be the LONGEST game in the world and could def have been a few more hours but you feel satisfied when you complete it. Side missions are actually really fun and diverse and a cool plot with twists and turns. Buy it now... DO IT!

One of the best games I've ever played! The story is amazing, the characters are heartwarming, funny and it's just so much fun to get through the game. Just let me say, it actually never gets boring to play that game. And it's impossible to NOT like the characters! If you are interested in good stories, neat graphics (yeah, this game is pretty old, but the graphics are also a + for the game okay!) and funny quotes as well as some good old fighting moments, then you'll have a lot of fun with that game. I also like the environment and the slighty futuristic touch in the game! :-)

This game has occupied many hours of my childhood as a player, and I had the opportunity to finish it on both PlayStation 2 and on GamingPC, in total I will have played this way for at least 250 hours. The game has a story that as not too complicated has very passionate and intrigued me to finish the game for even more than once.

This is one of the great games from my later childhood, one I would play for hours and hours, even though I didn't understand the plot, the game and its mechanics where just so enjoyable, and there are some rather interesting side activities in this old open worlds game. I hope to replay it at some point so I can fully understand its deep narrative and story, but for now I can fully recommend you this game merely on the basis of its great mechanics and the gameplay enjoyable, without even remembering how the plot that I didn't really get were! So please, buy this game, for your own good.

I've been interested in Beyond Good&Evil for a very long time but I never got around to picking the game up. Well, thanks to Steam I finally got a chance to try the game out for cheap, and MAN IS IT AWESOME! The game has a very intriguing storyline where, as Jade, you must use your skills as a photo-journalist...or a f***king ninja... to expose a sinister government ploy. 'Uncover the Conspiracy. Capture the Truth.' ALL the music in the game is just beautiful...seriously...DAT F**KING PIANO. Beyond Good&Evil also has a great visual style, which totally makes up for the graphical limitations of it's time. While playing through it, I just fell in love with the game. I loved all the interesting characters and it's whimsical tone, and I was very engaged in the story. I enjoyed Beyond Good&Evil IMMENSELY and it is easily one of my favourite games of all time. Please Ubisoft...we don't need another AC... WE NEED BEYOND GOOD & EVIL 2!

I played this game because I had heard good things about it, and I had to see for myself.  Truthfully, this PC port of the game has some minor glitchy problems, I only had random little screen glitches, but the game was still play-able. The game didn't crash for me at all, yet it kept saying my Graphic Card Drivers were out of date (They aren't) whenever I started the game up.  Now for the experience I had while playing this game was very nastolgic like. I never played this game before, yet it felt like I was right back in the Ps1-Ps2 era of console gaming. This game does have a lot to it, and one of the really great things about this game that stands out almost right away is the soundtrack.  The combat system in this game is really fun, but it doesn't expand as much as it should of. I only found one Attack powerup, but maybe I missed a hidden one somewhere.   The game is still challenging at parts.  The only downside I had with the game was learning the hard way that there is no Autosave. Save at the M-disk spots!  All in all, this game was a very fun experience and I already plan to play it through again one day.

I've wanted to play this game for a long time and this was the first time I've actually played through it. I really enjoyed it. The story, music, and world were a joy to experience and it's nice to play a game with the early aughts levity that you so seldom get in current games.   Now, would I recommend this for the PC? ....Not necessarily, it is horribly ported. Every time I launched the game it said my graphics card drivers were out of date (they weren't) Apparently, if you run this on a newer machine, the game can't recognize your graphics card and will just pop that error up every time you launch. You can click through it to boot the game up, though. Before you do that, I would suggest going into the advanced settings (not ingame), going into the manual compatibility settings and disabling HW Vertex Processing: it's job is to bug your game out with random polygons and artifacts that make the game unplayable. From what I've read, this happens to a lot of people.  Another problem with the port, this game was designed for a controller, yet there's no controller support. If you're like me, you're going to need to faff about extensively with the control settings to get the game marginally comfortable to play. One thing that I couldn't fix was how both the mouse and WSAD keys sent the same commands when you're in a vehicle and it screws with the camera. All in all, while I got through the game fine enough, it felt like I was limping the whole way because of the poor controls.  The game itself, though, was wonderful. As I took in the music, characters, and setting of the game I was sad that this never got the trilogy it promised to be. It's got a little of everything in it, stealth, action, vehicles, mini-games, puzzles, NPC interaction; its really remarkable that all of this was in it way back in the early 2000's and I felt the experience actually aged quite well. The lightly cartoony look did the game well and avoided the 'super realistic' games pitfal of looking and playing like ♥♥♥ now. It probably won't happen, but here's to hoping for that sequel to wrap things up!

Very underrated game which came out at a bad time and thus didn't get the attention it deserved. If you like games, and you haven't played this, you better pick it up now.  The only flaw (if you wanna call it that) are some of the stealth parts which can be really tricky).  9/10

I've been playing this game since it first came out. Give it to me on my GameCube, and make sure I don't get distracted for a good six hours, and I can 100% it no sweat.  This game means a lot to me because it features a female protagonist who knows what she values the most, and doesn't let things stand in her way. There are no shoehorned plot points to try and add extra volume to the story. Jade wants to protect her family, and that's what she does.   The running sidequest of taking pictures of every animal species on the planet is also really fun. It's really calming to know that you're helping with science, and it's a great revenue source.  I could go on and on about how much I love and adore this game, but that's not what the review feature is for. If it looks interesting, I reccomend with all my heart that you pick up this game and play it. Hopefully, you'll see how much you love it too.

+ fun camera mechanics to take pictuers of animals and monsters to earn credits and other currency + for the most part, the stealth sections are pretty enjoyable and lenient + great cast of characters + music is varied and fun to listen to + lots of stuff to find by exploring caves or locked doors around the town + the game is VERY lenient on pearl acquisition. you'll need a butt load for some sections of the game and there are places to scrounge up quite a bit of them. + story is fine. it's shallow but it gets the job done. it DOES do a good job as acting as a vehicle to give you more of a reporter/investigator role rather than pure combat. + checkpoints are more than fair. Honestly you'll be saving to avoid the game crashing and losing progress as apposed to losing a fight. Dying in any room or fight usually just places you right before the encounter.  - the most fighting you'll be doing in this game is against the camera. It's wonky, doesn't reset most of the time, and snaps you into awkward angles. - bugs. Jesus. This game is riddled with bugs. Sometimes its the AI partner freaking out but other times its more devious bugs like 'ran out of memory' and you having to restart the game. - texture issues a plenty. I couldn't get the launcher to readjust and show me settings, so I had to live with my initial settings which had textures going bonkers throughout the whole game. - the cliffhanger...  All in all it's something I think everyone should check out. The game itself is lots of fun but the running issues I noted above can slow your enthusiasm down.

Spoiler Free   It's showing its age a bit but it's still a good game. It has an interesting story with likable characters including a great, non-stereotypical protaganist. It's quite fun and the music is fantastic.   It isn't a great port though. The controls are dated and don't translate well to the PC, though they're not bad, but the camera is problematic at times, sometimes quite obnoxiously so, though it doesn't hamper the gameplay too much.   I've had various glitches while playing, such as the game telling me my drivers are out of date (Read: Nooooooppppe), and it occasionally minimizes. Your experience may vary of course.  The gameplay consists of flying, racing, combat, puzzle solving, and stealth sections. No particular facet of the gameplay is top tier nor terribly complex, but it all comes together nicely and is serviceable and enjoyable.   All-in-all, if you like fun, charming, adventure / platform games and can tolerate a few hiccups, you should definitely pick this up!

This game is a gem, overlooked since it came out during the high-point of platforming-action-adventures. Do you like 2000's action-adventures? Photography? Stealth? Melee comat? My major complaint about this game is that there are checkpoints during the final boss, which has rendered my game almost uncompletable by being low on health with no items, so I've not technically finished it, but I still love the game. Do NOT look over this one just because it's old. Let Ubisoft know we deserve that sequel!

6/10. The game is good in terms of plot, but once again, like Deep Space, I cannot give a thumbs up due to the controls on PC keyboard. It became obvious that this is a controller game based on the way the character loses behind the shoulder pov and goes to side scroller type, making it extremely difficult to get the main character to perform as you want. It doesn't mean it's impossible, it's merely frustrating as heck and required repeated plays in areas due to deaths that had nothing to do with fights. I had to play the game in short bursts rather than enjoy it in consecutive sittings. So you are warned about the controls before you choose to purchase the game to play with a PC Keyboard.   Pros: -Story -Length -Music -Jamaican Rhinos  Cons: -Keyboard controls -Changing camera pov -Last boss fight with reverse controls and never-ending repeated hitting in a pattern (I clocked 31 times in a row with no effect before throwing in the towel. If I happened to have had 99 K-lives as suggested before going into the final battle, maybe I would eventually have seen the end).

It's hard to recommend a good game that won't work on your computer. This game appears to be an old PC port of the game and has many graphic errors and is a pain to work with a controller. If you don't mind playing a good game with a lot of problems then buy away. If not then save your money and hope that Ubi actually provides the HD version of the game in the future.

A fantastic, if overrated game. It's certainly not the 'best game ever' or anything, despite what the cult following would say; but still, it's a solid adventure game in the veins of Okami, the Legend of Zelda or Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy. Definately worth a try if you either enjoy Zelda-style adventures, or haven't gotten sick of them yet.  However, this PC port is very old, very outdated, and has extreme difficulties running on modern hardware; errors such as forced 4:3, abysmal framerates, and constantly flickering textures and massive letterboxing making the game feel unplayably poor.  Available for free on Uplay, so not really worth purchasing here. Try either that, or the HD collection on 360/PS3.
Great game, aweful port. Wonky controls, bugs, graphic glitches and no controller support. Get it on PSN instead.

First of all, don't purchase this game on Steam unless you still have a Windows XP gaming system. There are a multitude of technical issues that will likely make it unplayable for you. So if you have an old console lying around it was on just about all of them, or play it on an emulator, Dolphin worked perfectly.  If you do put the effort into actually playing, there's not a lot to get excited about. Maybe it was a breath of fresh air in 2003 when it was released, but more than likely people only recommend it out of nostalgia.  It does play smoothly, and the pacing is nice, with some varied gameplay mechanics. The characters and world are on the verge of being interesting and lovable, but never quite gel. The plot is pretty saturday morning cartoony, and not in a good way.  If you, like me, wanted to check out a game touted as 'an underrated classic', I couldn't blame you for feeling the need to see for yourself. But if you never end up playing it, you didn't miss anything.  5.6/10
